title: English Soccer Star John Terry Buys £4.35 Million Country Manor
text:
Former soccer star John Terry, whose prominent career includes captaining both the England national team and premiership side Chelsea F.C., has splashed out on an 18th-century countryside mansion.



The defender and his wife, Toni, paid £4.35 million (US$5.35 million) in August for the brick and flint country house on the outskirts of the posh village of Cobham in Surrey, property records show.



More: Dusty Springfield’s Former London Home Now Asking £11.5 Million

Built in 1752, and with 20th century additions, the almost eight-acre property is accessed via a gated private drive, according to the listing from Savills, who declined to comment on the sale.



The seven-bedroom main house is entered through an entrance hall with a Georgian fireplace and a curved staircase, and it leads to the home’s drawing room, formal dining room, kitchen, sitting room and garden room, according to the listing.



Upstairs are the bedrooms, including a master suite—reached via a separate staircase—a guest suite, a library and a playroom.



The home’s previous owners “renovated and refurbished the property during their ownership, reinstating many of the period style features,” the listing said.



Attached to the main house is a three-bedroom annex with its own entrance, office space and a garage.

A barn on the grounds of the property is described in the listing as an “excellent entertaining space.” There’s also wine storage, a three-car garage, a stable block, a swimming pool and a tennis court, according to the listing.



Mr. Terry, 38, spent almost 20 years at Chelsea and is considered the team’s most successful captain, having led The Blues to five Premier League titles, four FA Cups, a UEFA Europa League title and a UEFA Champions League title—the most prestigious club competition in European football.



He currently serves as assistant head coach at Birmingham-based side Aston Villa, where he spent the last season of his playing career before retiring in 2018. Mr. Terry could not be reached for comment.



The Daily Mail first reported the sale.
